title: Astragalus: Benefits, side effects, and frequently asked questions
author: Louisa Richards
description: Astragalus is a herb that may have a range of health benefits. However, further conclusive research is necessary. Learn more here.

Astragalus membranaceus is the Latin name for the herb astragalus, [which is part of](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4791984/) Different species of astragalus grow worldwide in places such as Southwestern Asia, the Chinese Himalayan region, the Americas, and Europe. Human, laboratory, and animal studies indicate that the herbal extract may lower the likelihood of [bladder cancer](/articles/167077), increase the effectiveness of [chemotherapy](/articles/chemotherapy), and kill [gastric cancer](/articles/257341) cells. However, the quality of studies varies, and astragalus' anticancer effects are not conclusive. It is a good idea for a person with cancer to discuss suitable treatment options with their doctor. It may help with diabetes Laboratory [studies](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fphar.2020.00349/full) have demonstrated that astragalus polysaccharides can regulate [blood glucose](/articles/249413) and improve [insulin sensitivity](/articles/323027). Scientists note that astragalus may have the potential to play a key role in treating diabetes and its complications. In addition, the authors noted that astragalus species roots and aerial parts have anti-fibrotic and [diuretic](/articles/diuretics) actions. Anti-fibrotic agents prevent [scarring](/articles/325753). However, scientists conducted the study in a laboratory and will need to conduct additional research with human participants to make conclusive statements. It may have potential benefits for kidney disease A [small 2014 review](https://www.cochranelibrary.com/cdsr/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD008369.pub2/full) of 22 studies concluded that astragalus might have potential as an adjunctive treatment to conventional therapies for [chronic kidney disease](/articles/172179). However, the authors noted that most of the studies were not of high enough quality to make definite conclusions. A [small 2019 review](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0378874118332884) of 66 studies suggested that astragalus may be beneficial for [diabetic kidney disease](/articles/319686), but experts need further high quality studies to assess the herb's efficacy and safety.
